tips.content: Switch to rechargeable batteries to reduce hazardous waste from single-use batteries.
Over 40% of plastic produced is used just once before being discarded.
Replace disposable razors with a safety razor that uses replaceable blades.
Opt for loose-leaf tea instead of tea bags containing plastic microfibers.
The Great Pacific Garbage Patch is twice the size of Texas and mostly consists of microplastics.
Install a water-saving showerhead to reduce water usage by up to 50%.
Use a digital grocery list app to avoid impulse buys and reduce food waste.
Producing 1kg of beef emits 60kg of CO2—equivalent to driving 160 miles.
Meal prep for the week to minimize food packaging waste and spoilage.
Choose glass or metal food storage containers over plastic ones.
E-waste accounts for 70% of toxic waste in landfills but only 20% is recycled.
Repurpose old jars as storage containers or DIY candle holders.
Air-dry clothes instead of using a dryer to save energy.
A dripping faucet can waste over 3,000 gallons of water annually.
Fix leaky faucets and pipes in your home this weekend.
Donate old electronics to organizations that refurbish them.
It takes 500 years for a disposable diaper to decompose.
Try cloth diapers for babies to reduce landfill waste.
Use a broom instead of a hose to clean driveways and sidewalks.
Laundry microfiber pollution contributes to 35% of ocean microplastics.
Wash synthetic fabrics in a Guppyfriend bag to trap microfibers.
Buy secondhand furniture to reduce demand for new resources.

Install a dual-flush toilet or a water displacement device in your tank.
Opt for PDF tickets or mobile boarding passes to save paper.
Over 50 million tons of clothing are discarded globally each year.
Organize a clothing swap with friends or neighbors.
Use a menstrual cup or reusable pads to reduce sanitary waste.

Bring a reusable coffee cup to your favorite café for discounts.
Support brands with take-back programs for old products.
Over 8 million tons of plastic enter oceans annually—equivalent to a garbage truck per minute.
Avoid products with microbeads; choose natural exfoliants like oatmeal.
Use a solar-powered charger for small devices.
LED bulbs use 75% less energy and last 25x longer than incandescent bulbs.
Replace 5 light bulbs in your home with LEDs today.
Wrap gifts in fabric scraps or recycled newspaper.
The carbon footprint of a single email is about 4 grams of CO2.
Unsubscribe from unnecessary email newsletters to reduce digital clutter.
Buy local produce to cut down on transportation emissions.
Food transport accounts for 11% of global food system emissions.
Join a community-supported agriculture (CSA) program.
Use a pressure cooker to reduce cooking time and energy use.
Methane from food waste in landfills is 25x more potent than CO2.
Freeze leftover vegetable scraps to make homemade broth later.
Cancel junk mail by opting out through your local postal service.

Use a refillable pen instead of disposable plastic ones.

Offset your next flight’s carbon footprint through certified programs.
Choose powdered laundry detergent in cardboard packaging over liquid in plastic.
Only 9% of all plastic ever made has been recycled.
Write to companies urging them to adopt eco-friendly packaging.
Use a bidet attachment to reduce toilet paper consumption.

Switch to 100% recycled, unbleached toilet paper.
Make homemade cleaning solutions with vinegar and baking soda.

Dispose of hazardous waste (paint, batteries) at designated facilities.

Try a meatless Monday routine to reduce meat consumption.
Use a rainwater barrel to collect water for gardening.

Plant drought-resistant native plants in your garden.
Opt for digital magazines and books instead of print.

Donate old books to libraries or schools instead of trashing them.
Choose loose produce over pre-packaged items at the store.
